title: EU parliament will push Brexit down to the wire as MEPs threaten Boris Johnson
text:

The European Parliament is set to push Brexit down to the wire as MEPs threaten they will amend the withdrawal agreement when they have to vote on it.

MEPs want to wait for Westminster to pass the deal before they vote on it.

They are meeting for a plenary session in Strasbourg this week where they were due to vote but say they will not be able take the key decision on it because

At the moment the next opportunity for them to vote would be at a plenary in November.

But the EU is very keen for any delay to come from the UK side and not their own so they would likely hold an extraordinary plenary next week.

(Image: AFP/Getty Images)

MEPs have raised concerns that they will not have time to scrutinise the deal last week ahead of voting in Strasbourg.

The European Parliament’s Brexit Steering Group will advise the leadership of the EP that they shouldn’t approve the deal until it’s been “fully” ratified in the UK.

UK Green MEP Molly Scott Cato tweeted: "As MEP my job is to scrutinise Brexit deal to prevent damage to EU as, any member state or citizens

"This requires proper scrutiny: we won't be bounced by Boris Johnson .

"My clear view is that we won't be ready to pass it this week November more likely, hence extension inevitable

German Green MEP Terry Reintke agreed saying: " Not only for the unclarity of the developments in the British Parliament, but also for having the chance to properly debate in committees and groups in the EP we should postpone."

In theory MEPs could try and amend the agreement but sources suggest that is very unlikely to happen.

But they say any amendment to the deal which happens in the UK parliament this week would have to be examined.

If the UK moves towards a softer Brexit, such as backing a Customs Union, would pass through the European Parliament.

If Westminster make any changes that cross the EU's red lines then there could be problems.

There is growing demand within the EU Parliament for a delay but the EU member states, led by France, have ramped up talk of refusing any extension.

Mr Macron questioned the prospect of an extension on Saturday evening, after speaking to Mr Johnson.

A statement from the Élysée Palace said that he had sought "a swift clarification" from Mr Johnson and "signalled a delay would be in no one’s interest."

But despite a certain amount of genuine annoyance at a further delay, the EU27 would almost certainly grant one if the UK asked.
description: MEPs have shelved a vote which was scheduled for this week amid the chaos at Westminster
